com.tacticalenterprisesltd

Class Editor

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.tacticalenterprisesltd.Editor

  • public class Editor
extends java.lang.Object
    DataTables Editor base class for creating editable tables. Editor class instances are capable of servicing all of the requests that DataTables and Editor will make from the client-side - specifically:
    - Get data
    - Create new record
    - Edit existing records
    - Delete existing records

    This being the Java version of server side classes supporting DataTables, these classes will work strictly using Objects with the syntax:
    {"key1":"value1","key2":"value2","key3":{"subkey1":"value3","subkey2":"value4"}} or
    {"key1":"value1","key2":"value2","key3":[{"subkey1":"value3","subkey2":"value4"}]}
    For the purposes of providing inserts and updates of data, this syntax is mostly used and is best suited for OOP (Object Oriented Programming).

    On the client side and in PHP the concept of associative arrays does not exist in Java. The closest data structure resembling the associative array is the HashMap. In fact, to ensure that elements placed in HashMap came out in the same order while being processed by GSON, I had to resort to using a special version of HashMap called the LinkedHashMap. Therefore, I use the LinkedHashMap extensively throughout this library of classes.

    The Editor instance is configured with information regarding the database table fields that you wish to make editable, and other information needed to read and write to the database (table name for example!).

    Usage Example: A very basic example of using Editor to create a table with four fields. This is all that is needed on the server-side to create an editable table. The code below would be used in a Java Server Page or could be used even in a Servlet.

    String dbName = "fcs_db";
    String[] tableNames = new String[]{"employees"};
    String pKey = "ID";
    String[] fields = new String[]{"LASTNAME","FIRSTNAME","TITLE","EMAIL_ADDRESS"};
    Database db = new Database(dbName);
    Editor editor = new Editor(db, tableNames, pKey, params);
    Field field0 = new Field(tableNames[0],fields[0],Field.Type.STRING);
    field0.setValidator(new Validate(Validate.Type.REQUIRED));
    editor.addField(field0);
    Field field1 = new Field(tableNames[0],fields[1],Field.Type.STRING);
    field1.setValidator(new Validate(Validate.Type.REQUIRED));
    editor.addField(field1);
    Field field2 = new Field(tableNames[0],fields[2],Field.Type.STRING);
    editor.addField(field2);
    Field field3 = new Field(tableNames[0],fields[3],Field.Type.STRING);
    field3.setValidator(new Validate(Validate.Type.EMAIL_REQUIRED));
    editor.addField(field3);
    editor.Process();
    out.println(editor.toJSONString());
    Version:
    1.5.0
    Author:
    Alan Shiers

      • setJoinFieldsOnUpdateAndInsert

        public void setJoinFieldsOnUpdateAndInsert(boolean value,
                                  Field field,
                                  java.lang.String paramKey)
        Use this method on a Join when a Join has been flagged as READ ONLY. This means you've set its canWrite property to false and don't want to write to the database. However, in order to get any output from the join, you need to perform a lookup on the database in order to set the values on the Join fields during an Update operation. This method isn't used much, but comes in handy when you have a self referencing table.
        Parameters:
        value - Set to true when wanting to set the Join fields with values
        field - which will become part of a WhereCondition.
        paramKey - This would be a key used to perform a Parameter lookup to obtain a value for the field.

      • IncludeOptionsForOutput

        public void IncludeOptionsForOutput(java.lang.String key,
                           java.util.ArrayList<java.util.LinkedHashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> opts)
        In some scenarios on the client side you need to display all the possible options for a select dropdown combobox element or numerous checkboxes or radio buttons. To include any set of options for a SELECT query which will become part of the JSON string on output, you can use this method to load up any set of options through the use of a LinkedHashMap.
        Example:

        //OBTAIN ALL THE DEPARTMENT OPTIONS String value = "value"; String label = "label"; //Run a quick SELECT query to get the list of possible options on all departments String[][] result = editor.runSelectQuery(tableNames[1], "id", "name"); //all department options ArrayList> al = new ArrayList>(); LinkedHashMap row = null; for(int i = 0; i < result.length; i++) { row = new LinkedHashMap(); for(int j = 0; j < 2; j++) { if(j == 0) row.put(value, result[i][j]); else row.put(label, result[i][j]); } al.add(row); } LinkedHashMap deptOut = new LinkedHashMap(); deptOut.put("employees.dept",al); //deptOut now has all the options from the departments table. //Include this data using Editors method IncludeOptionsForOutput(LinkedHashMap opts) editor.IncludeOptionsForOutput(deptOut);
        Parameters:
        opts -

      • appendJSONData

        public java.lang.String appendJSONData(java.lang.String json1,
                              java.lang.String json2)
        Use this method to append a JSON string to an existing one. This method assumes that the first parameter json1 is a complete JSON representation of some data structure and the second parameter is represents some object structure. Usage:
        String json1 = "{ "data1":[...] }"
        String json2 = "{ "data2":[...] }"
        String result = appendJSONData(json1, json2);
        System.out.println(result);
        {"data1":[...],"data2"[...]}
        Parameters:
        json1 -
        json2 -
        Returns:
        A complete JSON string resultant from both JSON parameters.
